title: 110_hr4308
content: The Act may be cited as the "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007". It includes a section on the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by charitable donations or program proceeds. The Fund can be used for advertising and administrative expenses, with specific limits on expenditures. The "NASA Innovation Fund" can be used for advertising, administrative expenses, and prize money for competitions under section 314 of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958. The Fund can also be invested in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Investments in the "NASA Innovation Fund" can only be made in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. These obligations can be acquired on original issue or by purchasing outstanding obligations at market price. Any acquired obligation can be sold at market price, with the interest and proceeds credited to the Fund. SEC. 3. NASA INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise the Administrator on program implementation. The committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator. Members serve three-year terms with staggered initial terms for continuity. The Advisory Committee for the NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship shall have a Chair and Vice Chair appointed. Members serve three-year terms with staggered initial terms for continuity. Vacancies can be filled by the Administrator for the remainder of the term. Members cannot serve for more than 6 years and receive no compensation for their services. The Advisory Committee for the NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship appoints a Chair and Vice Chair, with members serving three-year terms. Vacancies are filled by the Administrator for the remainder of the term. Members cannot serve for more than 6 years and receive no compensation for their services. The Committee must meet at least 4 times a year, with the Administrator and Chief of Strategic Communications of NASA or their designees present to provide guidance. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship program is established under Section 4. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. A person approved for the program is known as a "sponsor". The logo will include the words "NASA Innovation Fund Partner" and an image chosen by the Advisory Committee. To become a sponsor, a person must submit an application to the Administrator. The application process for becoming a sponsor of the NASA Innovation Fund Partner program involves submitting a proposal with the amount to be contributed and a description of the promotional program using the Partnership Logo. The program should focus on educational information in STEM fields or promoting educational programs in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The NASA Innovation Fund Partner program requires sponsors to promote STEM education and opportunities in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Sponsors must enter into a sponsorship agreement with NASA, providing a specified amount and using the Partnership Logo in their promotional programs. Restrictions include not displaying logos on spacecraft. The NASA Innovation Fund Partner program requires sponsors to promote STEM education and opportunities in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Sponsors must enter into a sponsorship agreement with NASA, providing a specified amount and using the Partnership Logo in their promotional programs. Restrictions include not displaying logos on spacecraft, astronaut endorsements, agency-wide endorsements, in-kind contributions, minimum contribution levels, and other general restrictions. The Administrator establishes procedures to protect proprietary information. Congress encourages NASA to participate in STEM activities and provide assistance to sponsors. Enforcement measures are in place for unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo. Enforcement measures are in place for unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo, including civil actions and penalties for misuse. The Administrator can take legal action against sponsors who misuse the Partnership Logo. An annual report to Congress details NASA's actions and the Advisory Committee's activities. The Advisory Committee consults with NASA Centers annually to improve the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. SEC. 5 amends section 314(i) of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958. SEC. 6 defines key terms like Administrator, NASA, Partnership Logo, and Promotional program.
